title: Drug Overdose
summary: Life-threatening emergency requiring immediate medical care. Give naloxone if available for opioid overdose.

steps.title: Call 911 Immediately
steps.description: Call 911. Most states have Good Samaritan laws protecting those who call for overdoses. Tell dispatcher it's an overdose. Signs: unconsciousness, slow/no breathing, blue lips/fingernails, gurgling sounds.

steps.title: Check Breathing
steps.description: Check if person is breathing. If not breathing or breathing very slowly (less than 8 breaths/minute), begin rescue breathing or CPR. Try to wake person by calling name and rubbing knuckles on breastbone.

steps.title: Give Naloxone if Available
steps.description: For suspected opioid overdose, give naloxone (Narcan) if available. Spray in nostril or inject as directed. May need multiple doses every 2-3 minutes. Person may wake agitated - keep them calm.

steps.title: Position Safely
steps.description: If breathing but unconscious, place in recovery position (on side) to prevent choking. Stay with person. If they wake, do not let them use more drugs - overdose can return when naloxone wears off.

steps.title: Provide Information
steps.description: Tell paramedics: what drugs taken (if known), when taken, how much, if naloxone was given. Collect any drug containers or paraphernalia safely. Person needs hospital monitoring even if naloxone worked.

warnings: Overdose can return after naloxone wears off (30-90 minutes)
Never try to make person vomit
Mixing drugs, especially with alcohol, increases overdose risk
whenToSeekHelp: Call 911 immediately for all suspected overdoses
Even if person recovers with naloxone, they need hospital care
Call 911 if you're unsure - better safe than sorry
preventionTips: Never use alone - have someone who can call for help
Keep naloxone available if using opioids
Don't mix drugs or use with alcohol
